elements.content: A series of six hybrid polymers based on the mixed-valent {ε-PMoV 8MoVI 4O40Zn4} (εZn) Keggin unit have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using tritopic (1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (trim) or 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate (BTB)) or ditopic (4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (biphen)) linkers and [M­(bpy)3]2+ (M = Co, Ru) complexes as charge-compensating cations. (TBA)2[Co­(C10H8N2)3]­[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4]­(C27H15O6)4/3·1.5C27H18O6·24H2O (Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 ) has a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two interpenetrated networks and is isostructural to (TBA)4[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4]­(C27H15O6)4/3·1.5C27H18O6·8H2O (ε­(BTB) 4/3 ). In Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 , two tetrabutylammonium (TBA+) cations over the four present in ε­(BTB) 4/3 are replaced by one [Co­(bpy)3]2+ complex. [Co­(C10H8N2)3]­[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4]­(C9H3O6)­Co­(C10H8N2)4(H2O)·16H2O (Co-ε­(trim) (bpy) 2 ) is a 1D coordination polymer with two types of CoII-containing complexes, one covalently attached to the 1D chains and the other located in the voids as the counterion. [Ru­(C10H8N2)3]4[PMo12O38(OH)2Zn4]2(C9H3O6)2·42H2O (Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 ) and [Ru­(C10H8N2)3]3[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4Cl]2(C14H8O4)2·24H2O (Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 ) contain dimeric (εZn)2 units linked by dicarboxylate linkers, and both have [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ countercations. Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 has a 3D framework, while Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 is only 2D because of the presence of chloride ions on one-fourth of the ZnII ions. [P­(C6H5)4]6[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4]2(C9H3O6)2·18H2O (PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 ) is isostructural to Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 . These insoluble compounds entrapped in carbon-paste electrodes exhibit electrocatalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction. The effects of their structure and the nature of the counterions on the activity have been studied. For the first time, different POM-based coordination polymers are compared for catalytic H2 production using controlled-potential electrolysis. This study shows that the nature of the countercation has a strong effect on the electrocatalytic activity of the compound.

elements.content: The structure of polyoxometalate-based coordination polymers has been modulated from one-dimensional to three-dimensional by using di- or tricarboxylate linkers and various counterions. The catalytic H2 production by controlled-potential electrolysis of these materials depends on the nature of the counterions.

elements.content: Coordination polymers are hybrid organic–inorganic materials built of inorganic secondary building units (clusters, chains, or layers) assembled by coordination bonds between metal ions and polytopic organic linkers, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) being defined as porous coordination networks. In these last years, a new class of coordination polymers has emerged in which the inorganic building units are constituted by polyoxometalates (POMs) as an alternative to metal ions. Polyoxometalates are soluble anionic metal oxide clusters of d-block transition metals in high oxidation states (usually WVI, MoV,VI, VIV,V), and they exhibit properties that can be exploited in many fields ranging from magnetism, medicine, and photochromism to catalysis. POMs can be connected to each other via M–O–M′ (M, M′ = transition metal) linkages. They can also act as building units of hybrid materials, the connection being ensured by transition metal complexes or bridging organic ligands. Such polyoxometalate-based coordination polymers are sometimes called POMOFs. POMs are often considered as electron reservoirs, and their catalytic redox activity has attracted a lot of interest in recent years. Several studies have shown the potentialities of molecular POMs as electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), NOx reduction, oxygen reduction, and water oxidation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers are hybrid organic-inorganic materials built of inorganic secondary building units (clusters, chains, or layers) assembled by coordination bonds between metal ions and polytopic organic linkers, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) being defined as porous coordination networks. In these last years, a new class of coordination polymers has emerged in which the inorganic building units are constituted by polyoxometalates (POMs) as an alternative to metal ions. Polyoxometalates are soluble anionic metal oxide clusters of d-block transition metals in high oxidation states (usually WVI, MoV,VI, VIV,V), and they exhibit properties that can be exploited in many fields ranging from magnetism, medicine, and photochromism to catalysis. POMs can be connected to each other via M-O-M' (M, M' = transition metal) linkages. They can also act as building units of hybrid materials, the connection being ensured by transition metal complexes or bridging organic ligands. Such polyoxometalate-based coordination polymers are sometimes called POMOFs. POMs are often considered as electron reservoirs, and their catalytic redox activity has attracted a lot of interest in recent years. Several studies have shown the potentialities of molecular POMs as electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), NOx reduction, oxygen reduction, and water oxidation.

elements.content: Among these reactions, the HER is one of the most extensively studied electrochemical processes, as H2 may provide an alternative to hydrocarbon fuels because of its high energy content and environmentally benign nature. While platinum is known as a very efficient electrocatalyst for the reduction of protons, great efforts are now devoted to the replacement of this noble metal by cheaper and more abundant materials. Besides POMs, transition metal chalcogenides, nitrides and carbides, and molecular catalysts based on non-noble metal ions such as molybdenum, iron, cobalt, or nickel have thus been reported as rather efficient homogeneous cathode catalysts for the HER. However, homogeneous catalysis also suffers from several drawbacks, such as limited stability and uneasy catalyst recovery and recycling. Recent reports have thus focused on the heterogenization of active molecular catalysts via their incorporation into the framework of coordination polymers, including MOFs. Although these materials offer several advantages, there have been only a few reports on POM-based coordination polymers. Actually, they are synthesized in water in a one-step procedure, contain abundant and nontoxic metals, and operate in water at low overpotentials.

elements.content: In the context of our studies on POMOFs, we have selected the ε-Keggin POM unit, {ε-PMoV 8MoVI 4O40–x (OH) x Zn4} (0 ≤ x ≤ 4, denoted εZn; a), as it is particularly attractive for the construction of POM-based coordination polymers. In this mixed-valent POM, the electrons of the eight MoV ions are localized in four MoV–MoV bonds. The negatively charged [ε-PMoV 8MoVI 4O40]11– Keggin core is stabilized by ZnII capping ions and by protons located on bridging oxygen atoms. It thus presents the advantage of having four ZnII ions grafted at its surface in a tetrahedral arrangement available for coordinating ditopic linkers like 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, imidazole, 2-(2-pyridyl)­imidazole, or 4,4′-bipyridine or the tritopic 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (trim) linkers. We have also recently extended this family of POMOFs materials by using a mixture of two ligands, benzimidazole and a di- or a tricarboxylic acid.

elements.content: In almost all of the ε-Keggin based coordination polymers, tetrabutylammonium (TBA+) cations play the role of charge-compensating ions, but we have proposed that they might also act as structure-directing agents. These bulky ions occupy the voids delimited by the coordination networks so that none of these structures exhibit accessible porosity. Attempts to exchange these ligands by postsynthetic treatments have also failed. We thus thought to investigate new synthetic methods for replacing TBA+ cations by cationic coordination complexes, namely, [M­(bpy)3]2+ (M = Co, Ru; bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) complexes (b). This study might give new insights into (i) whether ε-Keggin-based coordination polymers could form in the absence of TBA+ counterions and (ii) whether additional electro­(photo)­chemical properties of POMOFs could be obtained by introducing the redox-noninnocent cationic [M­(bpy)3]2+ complexes. In addition, we have also attempted to replace the TBA+ cations with PPh4 + counterions, which have approximately the same size and charge (b). We thus report here the synthesis and characterization of four novel hybrid compounds with ε-Keggin POMs connected to di- or tricarboxylate linkers (c) and [M­(bpy)3]2+ (M = Co, Ru) or PPh4 + counterions. The electrochemical activity of these materials for the HER is also described.

elements.content: H3BTB, [Co­(bpy)3]­Cl2·6H2O, and [Ru­(bpy)3]­Cl2·6H2O were synthesized according to reported procedures. All of the other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Molybdenum powder (1–5 μm, >99.9% purity) was used for the synthesis. Hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. All of the reactants were briefly stirred before heating. The mixture was heated to 200 °C over a period of 1 h, kept at 200 °C for 70 h, and cooled to room temperature over a period of 80 h. The pH of the mixture was measured before (pHi) and after the reaction (pHf). The product was isolated by filtration after sonication (which allowed the removal of a brown powder that was always present after the reaction) and washed with ethanol. The crystalline homogeneity of each compound was checked by comparison of the experimental X-ray powder pattern with the powder pattern calculated from the structure solved from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figures SI1 and SI2). In Figure SI1, the powder patterns of the POMOFs with BTB linkers were compared to the powder pattern calculated from the structure recently called NENU-500.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Characterizations

H3BTB, [Co(bpy)3]Cl2⋅6H2O, and [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2⋅6H2O were synthesized according to reported procedures. All of the other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Molybdenum powder (1-5 μm, >99.9% purity) was used for the synthesis. Hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. All of the reactants were briefly stirred before heating. The mixture was heated to 200 °C over a period of 1 h, kept at 200 °C for 70 h, and cooled to room temperature over a period of 80 h. The pH of the mixture was measured before (pHi) and after the reaction (pHf). The product was isolated by filtration after sonication (which allowed the removal of a brown powder that was always present after the reaction) and washed with ethanol. The crystalline homogeneity of each compound was checked by comparison of the experimental X-ray powder pattern with the powder pattern calculated from the structure solved from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figures SI1 and SI2). In Figure SI1, the powder patterns of the POMOFs with BTB linkers were compared to the powder pattern calculated from the structure recently called NENU-500.

elements.content: A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.618 g, 0.50 mmol), metallic Mo (0.060 g, 0.62 mmol), H3PO3 (0.060 g, 0.75 mmol), Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.219 g, 1 mmol), H3BTB (0.400 g, 0.91 mmol), 40 wt % aqueous tetrabutylammonium hydroxide solution (200 μL, 0.30 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred, and the pH was adjusted to 6 with 4 M HCl (pHf = 5.7). Dark-red diplohedral crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction study were collected after filtration (0.108 g, 9.8% yield based on Zn). Anal. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections were carried out using Siemens SMART three-circle (Co-ε­(trim) (bpy) 2 ), Bruker Nonius X8 APEX 2 (PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 ), and Bruker AXS BV (Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 , Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 ) diffractometers, each equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector using the monochromatized wavelength λ­(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å. Absorption corrections were based on multiple and symmetry-equivalent reflections in the data set using the SADABS program based on the method of Blessing. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELX-TL package. Among the three PPh4 + cations, one cation could not be located properly in the structure of PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 because of severe disorder, and the data set was corrected with the program SQUEEZE, a part of the PLATON package of crystallographic software used to calculate the solvent or counterion disorder area and to remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. Crystallographic data are given in , and the complete data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Selected bond distances and valence bond calculations are given in Figures SI3–SI6. Valence bond calculations confirm the oxidation state of the Mo ions and indicate the presence of protons on bridging oxygen atoms of the POMs.

Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections were carried out using Siemens SMART three-circle (Co-ε(trim) (bpy)  2 ), Bruker Nonius X8 APEX 2 (PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2 ), and Bruker AXS BV (Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2 , Ru-ε  2  (biphen)  2 ) diffractometers, each equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector using the monochromatized wavelength λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å. Absorption corrections were based on multiple and symmetry-equivalent reflections in the data set using the SADABS program based on the method of Blessing. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELX-TL package. Among the three PPh4 + cations, one cation could not be located properly in the structure of PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2  because of severe disorder, and the data set was corrected with the program SQUEEZE, a part of the PLATON package of crystallographic software used to calculate the solvent or counterion disorder area and to remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. Crystallographic data are given in , and the complete data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Selected bond distances and valence bond calculations are given in Figures SI3-SI6. Valence bond calculations confirm the oxidation state of the Mo ions and indicate the presence of protons on bridging oxygen atoms of the POMs.

Powder X-ray diffraction data were obtained on a Bruker D5000 diffractometer using Cu radiation (1.54059 Å). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) measurements were performed on a JEOL JSM 5800LV apparatus. N2 adsorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K using a BELsorp Mini analyzer (Bel, Japan). Prior to the analysis, samples (∼50 mg) were evacuated at 90 °C under primary vacuum overnight.

elements.content: The electrochemical studies were conducted using an SP 300 potentiostat (Bio-Logic Science Instruments SAS) and an OrigaTrod rotating disc electrode (RDE) (OrigaLys). All of the electrochemical studies were performed at room temperature in an acidic medium (0.1 M H2SO4 at pH 1.0) using ultrapure water produced by a Millipore system (18.2 MΩ cm at 25 °C). Solutions were deaerated with nitrogen gas (99.998% purity) from Air Liquide for at least 15 min before all experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Studies

The electrochemical studies were conducted using an SP 300 potentiostat (Bio-Logic Science Instruments SAS) and an OrigaTrod rotating disc electrode (RDE) (OrigaLys). All of the electrochemical studies were performed at room temperature in an acidic medium (0.1 M H2SO4 at pH 1.0) using ultrapure water produced by a Millipore system (18.2 MΩ cm at 25 °C). Solutions were deaerated with nitrogen gas (99.998% purity) from Air Liquide for at least 15 min before all experiments.

elements.content: Because of the high insolubility of the POM-based coordination polymers in common solvents, the electrochemical behavior of these materials was studied in the solid state by entrapping them in a carbon-paste electrode. Bulk POMOF–carbon mixtures were prepared in a 1:2 weight ratio (5 mg of POM-based polymer and 10 mg of carbon black (Vulcan-XC72R, Cabot Corp.)) by hand agate mortar grinding to achieve a uniform mixture. A suspension of 1 mg of a POMOF–carbon mixture (hybrid catalyst) in 50 μL of ultrapure water was then prepared prior to all experiments.

A suspension of 1 mg of a POMOF-carbon mixture (hybrid catalyst) in 50 μL of ultrapure water was then prepared prior to all experiments.

elements.content: For cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), the modified electrodes were prepared by deposition of 30 μL of the hybrid catalyst on a 3 mm diameter glassy carbon (GC) disc electrode carefully polished with a wet polishing cloth using a 1 μm diamond suspension and a 0.05 μm alumina slurry (POMOF–carbon/GC). The deposits were dried under a small flow of argon and protected by deposition of Nafion (30 μL of 5% Nafion in ethanol). The Nafion layer was then left to dry under a small flow of argon to reach the final modified electrode (Nafion/POMOF–carbon/GC). The modified RDE electrodes used in LSV and electrolysis experiments were prepared using the same method by deposition of 50 μL of suspension on a 3 mm diameter GC electrode and 50 μL of Nafion 5% in ethanol (Nafion/POMOF–carbon/GC).

The deposits were dried under a small flow of argon and protected by deposition of Nafion (30 μL of 5% Nafion in ethanol). The Nafion layer was then left to dry under a small flow of argon to reach the final modified electrode (Nafion/POMOF-carbon/GC). The modified RDE electrodes used in LSV and electrolysis experiments were prepared using the same method by deposition of 50 μL of suspension on a 3 mm diameter GC electrode and 50 μL of Nafion 5% in ethanol (Nafion/POMOF-carbon/GC).

elements.content: CV (static electrode) and LSV (rotation speed 1000–2000 rpm) experiments were performed in a conventional three-electrode single-compartment cell. A Pt wire was used as the counter electrode and a saturated Ag/AgCl/KCl electrode (separated from the solution by a salt bridge) as the reference electrode. LSV measurements were conducted after 200 cycles of activation (stable LSV) in the range of 0.2 to −1 V vs Ag/AgCl at 100 mV s–1 and 2000 rpm to stabilize the current.

LSV measurements were conducted after 200 cycles of activation (stable LSV) in the range of 0.2 to -1 V vs Ag/AgCl at 100 mV s-1 and 2000 rpm to stabilize the current.

elements.content: Controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) experiments were carried out at room temperature in a gas-tight two-compartment electrochemical cell. The cathodic compartment was separated from the anodic compartment via a glass frit of fine porosity. The counter electrode was a platinum wire, and the reference electrode was a saturated Ag/AgCl/KCl electrode separated by a salt bridge. The activated Nafion/POMOF–carbon/GC electrodes were used as working electrodes. The solutions were purged with N2 gas for at least 15 min before electrolysis and were constantly stirred. Hydrogen bubbles formed on the surface of the working electrode and attached to it were removed by a brief rotation at 2000 rpm. Production of H2 in the headspace gas (22 mL) was measured by gas chromatography on a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector.

Hydrogen bubbles formed on the surface of the working electrode and attached to it were removed by a brief rotation at 2000 rpm. Production of H2 in the headspace gas (22 mL) was measured by gas chromatography on a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector.

elements.content: In order to verify any potential contamination of the POMOF–carbon mixture from the Pt counter electrode, different analyses were performed. The amount of Pt deposited onto the POMOF–carbon/GC electrodes was measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The samples (0.010 g of POMOF-carbon) after LSV were recuperated by rinsing the electrode surface with ethanol, digested with 3:1 HCl/HNO3 solution, and left to react for 48 h. It should be noted that different batches were accumulated to analyze a larger mass of sample. Then the sample mixture was diluted to 25 mL of doubly distilled water, filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE filter, and analyzed by a quadrupole-based ICP mass spectrometer (VG PQ Excell, Thermo Elemental). EDX analyses were also performed in order to detect the presence of Pt in the POMOF–carbon mixture after electrolysis.

Characterization of Hybrid Catalysts after Electrochemical Activation

In order to verify any potential contamination of the POMOF-carbon mixture from the Pt counter electrode, different analyses were performed. The amount of Pt deposited onto the POMOF-carbon/GC electrodes was measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The samples (0.010 g of POMOF-carbon) after LSV were recuperated by rinsing the electrode surface with ethanol, digested with 3:1 HCl/HNO3 solution, and left to react for 48 h. It should be noted that different batches were accumulated to analyze a larger mass of sample. Then the sample mixture was diluted to 25 mL of doubly distilled water, filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE filter, and analyzed by a quadrupole-based ICP mass spectrometer (VG PQ Excell, Thermo Elemental). EDX analyses were also performed in order to detect the presence of Pt in the POMOF-carbon mixture after electrolysis.

elements.content: Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 and ε­(BTB) 4/3 were obtained as black diplohedral crystals (Figure SI7) from the hydrothermal reaction of ammonium heptamolybdate, metallic Mo as a reducing agent, ZnII ions, H3BTB, and TBA­(OH). Compared with previously reported εZn-based POMOF materials, the synthesis was performed at higher pH (6). [Co­(bpy)3]­Cl2 was added as a substrate for the synthesis of Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 . The presence of TBA­(OH) was nevertheless required to get crystals, and it was thus impossible to replace all of the TBA+ cations in ε­(BTB) 4/3 . A compound close to ε­(BTB) 4/3 , called NENU-500, was recently reported. Its synthesis and chemical formula are slightly different from those of ε­(BTB) 4/3 . Elemental analysis of ε­(BTB) 4/3 showed a large excess of C that could only be explained by the presence of extra neutral linkers within the structure. This was confirmed by the presence of a CO vibration at νCO = 1698 cm–1 in the IR spectrum (Figure SI8a), characteristic of carboxyl COOH groups. These results, together with the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve (Figure SI9), allow the proposal of the detailed formula (TBA)4[PMoV 8MoVI 4O37(OH)3Zn4]­(BTB)4/3·1.5H3BTB·8H2O for ε­(BTB) 4/3 . The latter differs from that of NENU-500, (TBA)3[PMoV 8MoVI 4O36(OH)4Zn4]­(BTB)4/3·xGuest. The absence of visible white impurities, as well as the absence of extra peaks in the powder diffraction pattern (Figure SI1), suggests that the extra neutral H3BTB molecules do not cocrystallize with the POMOF but are rather encapsulated within the pores, as commonly observed during MOF synthesis. Attempts to remove the trapped H3BTB by washing the compound in hot N,N-dimethylformamide using a Soxhlet apparatus failed.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterizations

 Co-ε(BTB)  4/3  and ε(BTB)  4/3  were obtained as black diplohedral crystals (Figure SI7) from the hydrothermal reaction of ammonium heptamolybdate, metallic Mo as a reducing agent, ZnII ions, H3BTB, and TBA(OH). Compared with previously reported εZn-based POMOF materials, the synthesis was performed at higher pH (6). [Co(bpy)3]Cl2 was added as a substrate for the synthesis of Co-ε(BTB)  4/3 . The presence of TBA(OH) was nevertheless required to get crystals, and it was thus impossible to replace all of the TBA+ cations in ε(BTB)  4/3 . A compound close to ε(BTB)  4/3 , called NENU-500, was recently reported. Its synthesis and chemical formula are slightly different from those of ε(BTB)  4/3 . Elemental analysis of ε(BTB)  4/3  showed a large excess of C that could only be explained by the presence of extra neutral linkers within the structure. This was confirmed by the presence of a CO vibration at νCO = 1698 cm-1 in the IR spectrum (Figure SI8a), characteristic of carboxyl COOH groups. These results, together with the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve (Figure SI9), allow the proposal of the detailed formula (TBA)4[PMoV 8MoVI 4O37(OH)3Zn4](BTB)4/3⋅1.5H3BTB⋅8H2O for ε(BTB)  4/3 . The latter differs from that of NENU-500, (TBA)3[PMoV 8MoVI 4O36(OH)4Zn4](BTB)4/3⋅xGuest. The absence of visible white impurities, as well as the absence of extra peaks in the powder diffraction pattern (Figure SI1), suggests that the extra neutral H3BTB molecules do not cocrystallize with the POMOF but are rather encapsulated within the pores, as commonly observed during MOF synthesis. Attempts to remove the trapped H3BTB by washing the compound in hot N,N-dimethylformamide using a Soxhlet apparatus failed.

elements.content: Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 and ε­(BTB) 4/3 differ by the presence of one [Co­(bpy)3]2+, which replaces two TBA+ cations. In the IR spectrum of Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 , the presence of εZn POMs with Mo–O vibrations at around νMo–O = 920 and 780 cm–1, carboxylate linkers with C–O vibrations at νC–O = 1548, 1594, and 1698 cm–1, and TBA+ cations with C–H vibrations at around νC–H = 2900 cm–1 and at δC–H = 1466 cm–1 can be identified (Figure SI8a). However, the intensity of the bands attributed to TBA+ cations is lower in Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 than in ε­(BTB) 4/3 and new vibrations are assigned to the bpy ligands, thus confirming the partial substitution of TBA+ cations.

In the IR spectrum of Co-ε(BTB)  4/3 , the presence of εZn POMs with Mo-O vibrations at around νMo-O = 920 and 780 cm-1, carboxylate linkers with C-O vibrations at νC-O = 1548, 1594, and 1698 cm-1, and TBA+ cations with C-H vibrations at around νC-H = 2900 cm-1 and at δC-H = 1466 cm-1 can be identified (Figure SI8a). However, the intensity of the bands attributed to TBA+ cations is lower in Co-ε(BTB)  4/3  than in ε(BTB)  4/3  and new vibrations are assigned to the bpy ligands, thus confirming the partial substitution of TBA+ cations.

elements.content: Black crystals of Co-ε­(trim)­(bpy) 2 were isolated at pH 5.0 with trimesic acid in place of H3BTB. Under hydrothermal conditions, some of the [Co­(bpy)3]2+ complexes lose one bpy ligand, which then chelates ZnII ions of the ε-Keggin unit.
elements.clean_text: Black crystals of Co-ε(trim)(bpy)  2  were isolated at pH 5.0 with trimesic acid in place of H3BTB. Under hydrothermal conditions, some of the [Co(bpy)3]2+ complexes lose one bpy ligand, which then chelates ZnII ions of the ε-Keggin unit.

elements.content: Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 and Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 were isolated under similar conditions with [Ru­(bpy)3]­Cl2 as the reactant. As the Ru complex is more stable than its Co analogue, no decomposition could be observed. These phases are not isostructural with previously reported coordination polymers with TBA+ counterions. However, it was possible to synthesize PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , which is isostructural to Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 , thus allowing us to explore the influence of the counterions on the electrochemical properties. The IR spectra of Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 and PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 clearly show the presence of [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ and PPh4 + counterions, respectively (Figure SI8b).
elements.clean_text: Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2  and Ru-ε  2  (biphen)  2  were isolated under similar conditions with [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 as the reactant. As the Ru complex is more stable than its Co analogue, no decomposition could be observed. These phases are not isostructural with previously reported coordination polymers with TBA+ counterions. However, it was possible to synthesize PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2 , which is isostructural to Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2 , thus allowing us to explore the influence of the counterions on the electrochemical properties. The IR spectra of Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2  and PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2  clearly show the presence of [Ru(bpy)3]2+ and PPh4 + counterions, respectively (Figure SI8b).

elements.content: ε­(BTB) 4/3 is isostructural to NENU-500 (Figure SI1a). Its structure can be briefly described as a three-dimensional (3D) POMOF hybrid network with the monomeric mixed-valent POM {ε-PMoV 8MoVI 4O40Zn4} (a) as the inorganic building unit. Each of the four capping ZnII ions in tetrahedral coordination is bound to three oxygen atoms of the POM and to an oxygen atom of a BTB acting as a monodentate linker (a). The ligands are far from being planar, as commonly observed for structures with BTB. The connection of the POMs by the tritopic linkers generates two interpenetrated 3D networks (b). This network possesses a ctn topology (Figure SI10), which is one of the few predicted (3,4) periodic nets resulting from the linking of tetrahedral units with triangular linkers.

elements.content: In Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 , the molecular unit is the dimeric (εZn)2 POM, which results from the condensation of two Keggin units via two Zn–O bonds (a). Each of the six remaining Zn ions is coordinated to a monodentate carboxylate group of a trim linker. The resulting coordination network is 3D and is different from that in (TBA)3[PMo12O37(OH)3Zn4]­[C6H3(COO)3] (TBA-ε 2 (trim) 2 ), even though both structures incorporate dimeric units. In contrast, the use of PPh4 + cations leads to the formation of PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , which is isostructural to Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 .

elements.content: This can be explained by the orientations of the trim linkers, which are almost parallel in TBA-ε 2 (trim) 2 while they adopt two different orientations in Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 and PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 (Figure SI11). One εZn moiety of a dimeric unit is connected to three neighboring εZn POMs via trim linkers, forming a distorted honeycomb structure (b). The connections of POMs within the dimeric (εZn)2 units allows the connection of the planes into a 3D network (c). The negative charge of the network is compensated by three protons for one POM unit, located on the bridging oxygen atoms (Figure SI5), by three PPh4 + cations in PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , and by two protons and two [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ complexes in Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 . The positions of these counterions are shown in Figure SI12. No π–π interactions have been identified in any of these structures.

elements.content: In Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 , dimeric (εZn)2 POMs make bonds with monodentate biphen carboxylates (a). However, in contrast with Ru- and PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , this is true for only four Zn­(II) ions out of six, with the other two bearing terminal chloride ions coming from the [Ru­(bpy)3]­Cl2 precursor. Consequently, the structure is only 2D; the planes stack along the a axis (b,c). Three [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ complexes, one of which is disordered over two positions, occupy the voids delimited by the connection of the POMs and the biphen linkers, so the structure is very compact. It should be noted that the structure of this compound is different from that of ε 2 (biphen) 3 , the related compound previously reported with TBA+ counterions instead of Ru complexes.

elements.content: The electrochemical behavior of these POMOFs was studied in the solid state by entrapping them in a carbon-paste electrode as described in the . A suspension of a POMOF–carbon mixture in water was deposited on a previously polished glassy carbon (GC) electrode and was covered with a layer of Nafion. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were measured in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at potentials ranging from −0.25 to +0.55 V vs Ag/AgCl. In the following, potentials are related to the silver chloride electrode (E = 0.2 V vs NHE and −0.2 V vs ferrocene). We checked the stability of the compounds in the electrolyte solutions. The absence of any significant change in the IR spectrum and powder X-ray diffraction pattern of Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 (taken as a representative example of the family) stirred for 20 h in 0.1 M H2SO4 confirmed that this POMOF did not decompose in this aqueous medium (Figure SI13).
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Characterization

The electrochemical behavior of these POMOFs was studied in the solid state by entrapping them in a carbon-paste electrode as described in the . A suspension of a POMOF-carbon mixture in water was deposited on a previously polished glassy carbon (GC) electrode and was covered with a layer of Nafion. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were measured in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at potentials ranging from -0.25 to +0.55 V vs Ag/AgCl. In the following, potentials are related to the silver chloride electrode (E = 0.2 V vs NHE and -0.2 V vs ferrocene). We checked the stability of the compounds in the electrolyte solutions. The absence of any significant change in the IR spectrum and powder X-ray diffraction pattern of Ru-ε  2  (biphen)  2  (taken as a representative example of the family) stirred for 20 h in 0.1 M H2SO4 confirmed that this POMOF did not decompose in this aqueous medium (Figure SI13).

elements.content: The CVs displayed the three well-defined characteristic waves (I, II, and III) and a fourth anodic wave that in some cases was not well-defined (IV) ( and SI14–SI18). These bielectronic waves (I, II, and III) are assigned to three different MoVI/MoV redox processes of the Mo centers of the polyoxomolybdate ε-Keggin. Upon increasing the pH, a shift toward more cathodic potentials was observed for all of the redox processes, together with a decrease in the peak current intensity. This confirms the role of protons accompanying the reduction of the POM-based polymer by incorporating positive charges at the electrode surface to maintain neutrality according to the following equation: POMOF + 2 e − + 2 H + ⇄ H 2 POMOF

The E 1/2 values are independent of the scan rate, and the ratios of the current intensities (I pa/I pc) are ∼1, which suggests highly reversible processes.

elements.content: Figure SI19 displays CVs as a function of the scan rate, for ε­(BTB) 4/3 taken as a representative example of the family. The linear dependence of the peak current intensity with respect to the scan rate is consistent with a surface-controlled redox process. Similarly, the CV recorded at a high rotation rate gives the same profile as the static CV, which confirms that the process is not governed by diffusion of the species in solution but rather is due to an adsorbed species (see the example of Co-ε­(trim)­(bpy)2 , Figure SI20).

elements.content: The E 1/2 values for wave II (E 1/2(II)) are the same for all of the materials and seem unaffected by the structural or counterion variations. On the contrary, the E 1/2(I) and E 1/2(III) values vary slightly depending on these parameters. Indeed, the main peak potential for redox couple I was found to be E 1/2(I) = −0.07 V vs Ag/AgCl for Co-ε­(trim)­(bpy) 2 , ε­(BTB) 4/3 , and Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 and E 1/2(I) ≈ −0.09 V vs Ag/AgCl for Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 , PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , and Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 . The frameworks with dimeric (εZn)2 POM units tend to have lower E 1/2(I) values than those with monomeric POM units. The same trend was observed for E 1/2(III). Moreover, the counterion has a slight influence on the E 1/2(III) value, as can be seen from comparison within the ε 2 (trim) 2 -type frameworks (E 1/2(III) = 0.32 V for Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 and E 1/2(III) = 0.30 V for PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 ).

elements.content: The HER catalytic activities of the POM-based coordination polymers were evaluated by LSV reaching negative potentials down to −1 V vs Ag/AgCl. The POMOF–carbon mixture was deposited on a GC electrode as described in the . These experiments were conducted in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solutions (pH 1.0) using an RDE rotating at 2000 rpm. For all of the compounds, at potentials below −0.6 V vs Ag/AgCl a catalytic wave was observed and assigned to the reduction of protons. After this scan, the characteristic CV observed for these compounds could not be recovered (see Figure SI21). This behavior has been attributed to a multielectronic irreversible reduction process of Mo species. To reach their maximum HER activities, the materials were thus activated by a cycling process (200 cycles) from 0.2 to −1 V at a scan rate of 100 mV s–1 (Figure SI22). During these cycles, the activity gradually increased to reach a maximum onset potential ranging from −260 to −450 mV (). Thus, the initial POM-based polymers act as precatalysts for the formation of HER-active materials, although the mechanism of this activation remains unknown. The formation of platinum nanoparticles on the electrode surface as suggested by Kulesza and co-workers and Zhang et al. was not evidenced. Indeed, both EDX and ICP-MS analyses failed to reveal the presence of any Pt (minimum concentration detected ≤1 ppb). shows the LSV curves after the activation process of the POMOF materials. Since a solar-light-coupled HER apparatus usually runs at a current density of 10–20 mA cm–2, the overpotential for a current of 10 mA cm–2 (η10) was chosen as a point of reference to compare the HER activities of the materials ().

On the basis of the onset potential (V onset) and overpotential values, three groups of POMOF materials can be distinguished. Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 and PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 have the lowest V onset (around −260 and −270 mV vs Ag/AgCl, respectively) and the lowest η10 value (∼336 mV), Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 has the highest values, and the three other materials, Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 , ε­(BTB) 4/3 , and Co-ε­(trim) (bpy) 2 , have intermediate values.

elements.content: To confirm the electrocatalytic HER and examine the durability of these POM-based polymer materials, CPE experiments were conducted at −0.6 V vs Ag/AgCl in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at pH 1.0. The first direct observation of the production of hydrogen is the intense formation of bubbles at the surface of the electrode shortly after the beginning of the CPE. H2 production was measured during CPE experiments by gas chromatography ( and ). We observed that the production of H2 for all of the catalysts studied here reached a plateau at around 60 min. Faradaic yields (FYs) are calculated after 60 min of reaction, yielding values of around 60%, which is underestimated since the charge consumed to reach the active reduced Mo species has not been taken into account.
elements.clean_text:
Controlled-Potential Electrolysis

To confirm the electrocatalytic HER and examine the durability of these POM-based polymer materials, CPE experiments were conducted at -0.6 V vs Ag/AgCl in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at pH 1.0. The first direct observation of the production of hydrogen is the intense formation of bubbles at the surface of the electrode shortly after the beginning of the CPE. H2 production was measured during CPE experiments by gas chromatography ( and ). We observed that the production of H2 for all of the catalysts studied here reached a plateau at around 60 min. Faradaic yields (FYs) are calculated after 60 min of reaction, yielding values of around 60%, which is underestimated since the charge consumed to reach the active reduced Mo species has not been taken into account.

elements.content: Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 and PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , which have the lowest η10 values, also have the highest H2 evolution rates, while Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 is the least active compound. A trend in the effect of the cations in the POM-based polymers on the HER arises from these results. The presence of big divalent counterions such as [M­(bpy)3]2+ (M = Co, Ru) tends to decrease the catalytic performance of the material compared to the presence of monovalent cations like TBA+ or PPh4 +. Indeed, for the isostructural ε 2 (trim) 2 -type frameworks, PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 is far more active than Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 . On the contrary, neither the dimensionality of the framework nor the nature of the POM building unit seems to have an effect on the catalytic activity.

Indeed, for the isostructural ε  2  (trim)  2 -type frameworks, PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2  is far more active than Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2 . elements.content: We have demonstrated for the first time that the TBA+ counterions usually present in ε-Keggin-based coordination polymers may be replaced in situ, partially or totally, with [M­(bpy)3]2+ (M = Ru, Co) or PPh4 + counterions. In Co-ε­(BTB) 4/3 , half of the TBA+ cations were substituted, leaving the hybrid structure of the compound unchanged compared with the structure with TBA+ cations only. By contrast, there are no TBA+ cations left in the three novel coordination polymers PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 , Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 , and Ru-ε 2 (biphen) 2 which contain PPh4 + cations or [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ as countercations. Also, their structures are different from those of their analogues containing TBA+ counterions, showing that the counterions indeed have a structure-directing role. Furthermore, it has been possible to isolate the unprecedented 1D coordination polymer Co-ε­(trim)­(bpy) 2 with two types of CoII-containing complexes, one covalently attached to the 1D chains and the other located in the voids as counterions. Finally, these materials act as precatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Their activity depends strongly on the nature of the counterions. PPh 4 -ε 2 (trim) 2 is the most efficient compound in terms of onset potential (−270 mV) and hydrogen production. The comparison of its activity with that of the isostructural Ru-ε 2 (trim) 2 suggests that monocationic counterions are more favorable than dicationic ones for the electrocatalytic activity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have demonstrated for the first time that the TBA+ counterions usually present in ε-Keggin-based coordination polymers may be replaced in situ, partially or totally, with [M(bpy)3]2+ (M = Ru, Co) or PPh4 + counterions. In Co-ε(BTB)  4/3 , half of the TBA+ cations were substituted, leaving the hybrid structure of the compound unchanged compared with the structure with TBA+ cations only. By contrast, there are no TBA+ cations left in the three novel coordination polymers PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2 , Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2 , and Ru-ε  2  (biphen)  2  which contain PPh4 + cations or [Ru(bpy)3]2+ as countercations. Also, their structures are different from those of their analogues containing TBA+ counterions, showing that the counterions indeed have a structure-directing role. Furthermore, it has been possible to isolate the unprecedented 1D coordination polymer Co-ε(trim)(bpy)  2  with two types of CoII-containing complexes, one covalently attached to the 1D chains and the other located in the voids as counterions. Finally, these materials act as precatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Their activity depends strongly on the nature of the counterions. PPh  4  -ε  2  (trim)  2  is the most efficient compound in terms of onset potential (-270 mV) and hydrogen production. The comparison of its activity with that of the isostructural Ru-ε  2  (trim)  2  suggests that monocationic counterions are more favorable than dicationic ones for the electrocatalytic activity.
